" d = water depth in the canal

The canals are open or closed conduits in which the water circulates due to the action of gravity and without any pressure, because the free surface of the liquid is in contact with the atmosphere This means that water flows driven by atmospheric pressure and by its own weight.

They include all the water courses that exist naturally in the land, which vary in size from small streams in mountainous areas, to streams, small and large rivers streams, lakes and lagoons. Underground currents are also considered natural channels. The transverse section of a natural channel is generally very irregular and variable within its path.

Artificial canals are all those built or developed by the effort of the hand of man, such as: irrigation canals, navigation, flood control, canals of hydroelectric centrals, storm sewer, sanitary, overflow canals, wooden gutters, ditches along roads, agricultural drainage ditches and built-model canals at the laboratory. Artificial canals are usually designed with regular geometric shapes, also called binoculars, a canal built with an invariable cross section and a constant bottom slope is known as a prismatic canal.
It is used in ground channels because they provide the necessary slopes to stabilize ,and in coated canals
Because the rectangle has vertical sides, it is usually used for canals built with stable materials, wooden aqueducts, for canals excavated in rock and for coated canals.
It is used for covered gutters on roads, also on waterways small earth, mainly for ease of stroke. They are also used coated, as sewers of the roads.
The circle is the most common section for sewers and sewers of small and medium sizes.

Geometric elements are properties of a canal section that can be defined completely by the geometry of the section and the depth of the flow. The most well-known form of the section cross section of a canal is the trapezoidal.
It is the vertical distance from the lowest point of a section of the canal up to the free surface, that is, the maximum depth.
It is the width of the free surface of the water, in m

It is the ratio of the horizontal projection to the vertical of the side wall (It is also called the slope of the walls of the canal). That is, "m" is the value of the projection when the vertical is 1. It is expressed as the cotangent of the angle of repose of the material.
It depends on the type of material in which the canal is housed.
It is the surface occupied by water in a cross section normal any, is expressed in m²
It is the longitudinal slope of the grade of the material.
It is the length of the contour line of the wet area between the water and the walls of the canal, expressed in m
It is the quotient of the hydraulic area and the wet perimeter.
It is the volume of water that passes in the cross section of the channel in the unit time, and is expressed in m³/s
It is the one with which the water flows in the channel, expressed in m/s
It is the effect of gravity on the state of flow represented by the relationship between inertial forces and gravitational forces.

Where: "
" "
" Q = expense in m³/s "
" n = Manning roughness coefficient "
" S = hydraulic slope of the canal "
" A = hydraulic canal area in m² "
" R = hydraulic radius in m
